title: gFormulaMI - G-formula for causal inference via multiple imputation
text: vignette introduce functionality gFormulaMI. package implements approach constructing G-formula estimator using multiple imputation methods software, described Bartlett et al (2023). First use simulated dataset provided package demonstrate impute potential outcomes using gFormulaImpute. show resulting imputed datasets can analysed using syntheticPool function. Lastly, illustrate functions can used dataset missing values begin (.e. regular missing data).

title: gFormulaMI - G-formula for causal inference via multiple imputation
text: First, load package first rows simulated dataset ships package look like l variables correspond confounder measured baseline (l0) two follow-time points (l1 l2). time-varying binary treatment variable stored a0, a1 a2. final outcome variable y. Next use gFormulaImpute impute potential outcomes two treatment regimes interest. , gFormulaImpute uses mice multiple imputation function mice package. passed regular data frame, , gFormulaImpute expects (requires) missing values data frame. run, tell gFormulaImpute variables correspond time-varying treatment treatment regime(s) want create imputations : called gFormulaImpute requesting 10 imputations generated two regimes interest, corresponding treatment time point (0,0,0) treatment time point (1,1,1).

title: gFormulaMI - G-formula for causal inference via multiple imputation
text: printed output tells us imputation methods used impute (simulate) time-varying confounders outcome. default, gFormulaImpute specifies impute numeric variables using normal linear regression, l0, l1, l2 y imputed using method norm. binary factors time-varying confounders, imputed using logistic regression. Factor time-varying confounders unordered imputed using polytomous regression proportional odds model used ordered factors. want modify defaults, can pass method vector gFormulaImpute, specifies imputation methods available mice package use imputing column data frame. output also shows predictorMatrix argument used calling mice imputation function. shows, given row, variables (indicated 1) used covariates imputation model variable labelled row. Thus , l1 imputed using l0 a0. variables imputed (indicated empty entry vector imputation methods printed), corresponding row predictor matrix effect anything. particular, treatment variables a0, a1 a2 imputed based regression model. notice printed predictorMatrix 1s lower diagonal 0s upper diagonal. g-formula hence gFormulaImpute, imputes sequentially forwards time, using past (.e. left) variables covariates. , data frame pass gFormulaImpute must variables ordered time example , correct covariates used model. wish modify predictor matrix used, can pass custom one using predictorMatrix argument gFormulaImpute. Note unlike usual missing data situation, iteration required gFormulaImpute calls mice imputation function, thus gFormulaImpute calls mice sets maxit argument 1.

title: gFormulaMI - G-formula for causal inference via multiple imputation
text: call asked gFormulaImpute create 10 imputations. Later analyse imputations, special pooling rules apply can, small number imputations, produce negative variances parameter estimates. avoid , recommend using least 25 imputations general (used 10 sake speed).

title: gFormulaMI - G-formula for causal inference via multiple imputation
text: call specify nSim argument. argument specifies many individuals simulate longitudinal histories synthetic imputed datasets. Since specify value, default simulate number number rows data frame passed gFormulaImpute (5,000). one treatment regime specified, nSim rows simulated regime.

title: gFormulaMI - G-formula for causal inference via multiple imputation
text: gFormulaImpute creates set synthetic imputed datasets. , imputed datasets created contain imputed (simulated) longitudinal histories based fitted models, treatment regimes specified. original rows data frame passed gFormulaImpute appear imputed datasets returned us. first rows first imputed dataset : see first rows first imputed dataset, a0, a1 a2 always zero, first treatment regime specified impute (0,0,0). also additional variable, called regime. factor variable records specified treatment regimes row corresponds . Thus , first rows data frame, regime 1. analyse imputed datasets first run desired analysis imputed longitudinal histories. simply compare mean final outcome variable y two regimes imputed . , fit linear model y dependent variable regime covariate: imputed datasets analysed fully synthetic, (rather ) pool estimates using Rubin’s standard combination rules (e.g. implemented pool mice package). results variances larger . Instead use synthetic imputation combination rules developed Raghunathan et al (2003), implemented syntheticPool function: intercept corresponds mean y first regime (0,0,0). factor(regime)2 coefficient corresponds difference mean y second regime first. see second regime mean outcome 3 higher first. well point estimate, see within, total imputation variances. can see total variances less , never happens Rubin’s regular pooling rules. synthetic pooling rules Raghunthan et al (2003), total variance minus within imputation variance (plus correction finite number imputations performed).

title: gFormulaMI - G-formula for causal inference via multiple imputation
text: Often longitudinal dataset missing values. context, one approach use multiple imputation impute missing values using imputation software, assuming missing random. imputed , can pass imputed datasets gFormulaImpute perform synthetic imputation step. illustrate steps, let’s now create new dataset simulated one, making values missing: simply made around 20% values missing l0, l1, l2 y, completely randomly. Next, impute simDataMissing data frame using mice function: real substantive analysis take care think specify imputation models. discussion point, see Bartlett et al (2023). particular, note default behaviour mice function impute numeric variables using predictive mean matching method, rather normal linear regression (gFormulaImpute function). can now pass multiply imputed datasets gFormulaImpute create synthetic imputations , time let’s try generate 20 synthetic imputated datasets: output looks much first time called gFormulaImpute, apart first lines output. gFormulaImpute can see 10 imputations original dataset, refuses generate different number imputations number mids multiple imputation dataset object passed . imps2 object thus contains 10 imputations, can analysed using syntheticPool way .
code: simDataMissing <- simDataFullyObs simDataMissing$l0[runif(nrow(simDataMissing))<0.2] <- NA simDataMissing$l1[runif(nrow(simDataMissing))<0.2] <- NA simDataMissing$l2[runif(nrow(simDataMissing))<0.2] <- NA simDataMissing$y[runif(nrow(simDataMissing))<0.2] <- NA simDataMissingImps <- mice::mice(simDataMissing,m=10,printFlag=FALSE) imps2 <- gFormulaImpute(data=simDataMissingImps,M=20,trtVars=c("a0","a1","a2"),                         trtRegimes=list(c(0,0,0),c(1,1,1))) #> [1] "Input data is a mice created multiple imputation object." #> [1] "Value passed to M being ignored." #> [1] "Number of synthetic imputations to be generated set to 10 as in mids object passed to gFormulaImpute." #> [1] "Variables imputed using:" #>     l0     a0     l1     a1     l2     a2      y regime  #> "norm"     "" "norm"     "" "norm"     "" "norm"     ""  #> [1] "Predictor matrix is set to:" #>        l0 a0 l1 a1 l2 a2 y regime #> l0      0  0  0  0  0  0 0      0 #> a0      1  0  0  0  0  0 0      0 #> l1      1  1  0  0  0  0 0      0 #> a1      1  1  1  0  0  0 0      0 #> l2      1  1  1  1  0  0 0      0 #> a2      1  1  1  1  1  0 0      0 #> y       1  1  1  1  1  1 0      0 #> regime  1  1  1  1  1  1 1      0

title: gFormulaMI - G-formula for causal inference via multiple imputation
text: Bartlett JW, Olarte Parra C, Daniel RM. G-formula causal inference via multiple imputation. 2023 arXiv 2301.12026 Raghunathan TE, Reiter JP, Rubin DB. 2003. Multiple imputation statistical disclosure limitation. Journal Official Statistics, 19(1), p.1-16.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Jonathan Bartlett. Author, maintainer.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Bartlett J (2023). gFormulaMI: G-formula causal inference via multiple imputation. R package version 0.0.1, https://jwb133.github.io/gFormulaMI/.
code: @Manual{,   title = {gFormulaMI: G-formula for causal inference via multiple imputation},   author = {Jonathan Bartlett},   year = {2023},   note = {R package version 0.0.1},   url = {https://jwb133.github.io/gFormulaMI/}, }

title: G-formula multiple imputation — gFormulaImpute
text: gFormulaImpute creates multiple imputed synthetic datasets longitudinal histories specified treatment regimes interest, based G-formula.

title: G-formula multiple imputation — gFormulaImpute
code: gFormulaImpute(   data,   M = 50,   trtVars,   trtRegimes,   nSim = NULL,   micePrintFlag = FALSE,   silent = FALSE,   method = NULL,   predictorMatrix = NULL )

title: G-formula multiple imputation — gFormulaImpute
text: data observed data frame M number imputed datasets generate trtVars vector variable names indicating time-varying treatment variables nSim number individuals simulate imputed dataset. Defaults number individuals observed data micePrintFlag TRUE/FALSE specifying whether output call(s) mice printed silent TRUE/FALSE indicating whether print output console (FALSE) (TRUE) method optional method argument pass mice. specified, default impute continuous variables using normal linear regression (norm), binary variables using logistic regression (logreg), polytomous regression unordered factors proportional odds model ordered factors predictorMatrix optional predictor matrix specify variables use predictors imputation models. default impute sequentially, .e. impute using variables left variable imputed covariates

title: G-formula multiple imputation — gFormulaImpute
text: S3 object class mids (multiply imputed dataset)

title: G-formula multiple imputation — gFormulaImpute
text: gFormulaImpute creates multiple imputed synthetic datasets longitudinal histories specified treatment regimes interest, based G-formula, described Bartlett et al 2023. Specifically, observed data frame, additional nSim rows added variables set missing, except time-varying treatment variables. latter set values specified trtRegimes argument. multiple treatment regimes specified, nSim rows added specified treatment regimes. gFormulaImpute uses mice package impute potential outcome values time-varying confounders outcome synthetic datasets. Imputation performed sequentially left right data frame. , variables must ordered time input data frame, time-varying confounders time followed corresponding treatment variable time. data argument, gFormulaImpute expects either fully observed (complete) data frame, else set multiple imputation stored object class mids (mice package). Unlike Rubin's regular multiple imputation pooling rules, possible pooling rules developed Raghunathan et al (2003) give negative variance estimates. probability occurring reduced increasing M /nSim. gFormulaImpute returns object class mids. can analysed using methods imputed datasets mice can analysed (see examples). However, Rubin's standard pooling rules valid analysis synthetic datasets. Instead, synthetic variance estimator Raghunathan et al (2003) must used, implemented syntheticPool function. development gFormulaMI package supported grant UK Medical Research Council (MR/T023953/1).

title: G-formula multiple imputation — gFormulaImpute
text: Bartlett JW, Olarte Parra C, Daniel RM. G-formula causal inference via multiple imputation. 2023 https://arxiv.org/abs/2301.12026 Raghunathan TE, Reiter JP, Rubin DB. 2003. Multiple imputation statistical disclosure limitation. Journal Official Statistics, 19(1), p.1-16.

title: G-formula multiple imputation — gFormulaImpute
text: Jonathan Bartlett jonathan.bartlett1@lshtm.ac.uk

title: G-formula multiple imputation — gFormulaImpute
code: set.seed(7626) #impute synthetic datasets under two regimes of interest imps <- gFormulaImpute(data=simDataFullyObs,M=10,                         trtVars=c("a0","a1","a2"),                         trtRegimes=list(c(0,0,0),c(1,1,1))) #> [1] "Input data is a regular data frame." #> [1] "Variables imputed using:" #>     l0     a0     l1     a1     l2     a2      y regime  #> "norm"     "" "norm"     "" "norm"     "" "norm"     ""  #> [1] "Predictor matrix is set to:" #>        l0 a0 l1 a1 l2 a2 y regime #> l0      0  0  0  0  0  0 0      0 #> a0      1  0  0  0  0  0 0      0 #> l1      1  1  0  0  0  0 0      0 #> a1      1  1  1  0  0  0 0      0 #> l2      1  1  1  1  0  0 0      0 #> a2      1  1  1  1  1  0 0      0 #> y       1  1  1  1  1  1 0      0 #> regime  1  1  1  1  1  1 1      0 #fit linear model to final outcome with regime as covariate fits <- with(imps, lm(y~factor(regime))) #pool results using Raghunathan et al 2003 rules syntheticPool(fits) #>                    Estimate       Within     Between       Total       df #> (Intercept)     -0.02071539 0.0008125695 0.001763004 0.001126735 3.038045 #> factor(regime)2  2.96593502 0.0016251389 0.004203106 0.002998278 3.784951 #>                   95% CI L   95% CI U            p #> (Intercept)     -0.1267874 0.08535658 5.803156e-01 #> factor(regime)2  2.8104386 3.12143146 1.304839e-06

what: Simulated fully observed data frame — simDataFullyObs
title: Simulated fully observed data frame — simDataFullyObs
text: simulated observational study data frame missing data.

title: Simulated fully observed data frame — simDataFullyObs
Simulated fully observed data frame — simDataFullyObs
text: data frame 5000 rows following variables: l0 Continuous baseline confounder a0 Binary baseline treatment l1 Continuous confounder time 1 a1 Binary treatment time 1 l2 Continuous confounder time 2 a2 Binary treatment time 2 y Continuous final outcome

what: Pool estimates and variances obtained by analysing multiple synthetic datasets — syntheticPool
title: Pool estimates and variances obtained by analysing multiple synthetic datasets — syntheticPool
text: function pools estimates variances obtained analysing multiple synthetic imputations (e.g. created used gFormulaImpute) using method developed Raghunathan et al 2003.

title: Pool estimates and variances obtained by analysing multiple synthetic datasets — syntheticPool
Pool estimates and variances obtained by analysing multiple synthetic datasets — syntheticPool
text: fits Collection model fits produced call form (imps, lm(y~regime)) imps collection imputed datasets class mids.

title: Pool estimates and variances obtained by analysing multiple synthetic datasets — syntheticPool
text: matrix containing pooled results.

title: Pool estimates and variances obtained by analysing multiple synthetic datasets — syntheticPool
text: argument syntheticPool set model fits obtained running analysis imputed dataset collection class mids, created example using mice function mice package. function returns table containing overall parameter estimates, within, total imputation variances, 95% confidence intervals, p-values testing null hypothesis corresponding parameters equal zero. possible variance estimator developed Raghunathan et al 2003 negative. case syntheticPool stops informs re-impute using larger number imputations M /nSim. development gFormulaMI package supported grant UK Medical Research Council (MR/T023953/1).

title: Pool estimates and variances obtained by analysing multiple synthetic datasets — syntheticPool
text: Raghunathan TE, Reiter JP, Rubin DB. 2003. Multiple imputation statistical disclosure limitation. Journal Official Statistics, 19(1), p.1-16.

title: Pool estimates and variances obtained by analysing multiple synthetic datasets — syntheticPool
text: Jonathan Bartlett jonathan.bartlett1@lshtm.ac.uk

title: Pool estimates and variances obtained by analysing multiple synthetic datasets — syntheticPool
code: set.seed(7626) #impute synthetic datasets under two regimes of interest using gFormulaImpute imps <- gFormulaImpute(data=simDataFullyObs,M=10,trtVarStem="a",                         timePoints=3,                         trtRegimes=list(c(0,0,0),c(1,1,1))) #> Error in gFormulaImpute(data = simDataFullyObs, M = 10, trtVarStem = "a",     timePoints = 3, trtRegimes = list(c(0, 0, 0), c(1, 1, 1))): unused arguments (trtVarStem = "a", timePoints = 3) #fit linear model to final outcome with regime as covariate fits <- with(imps, lm(y~factor(regime))) #> Error in eval(expr, envir, enclos): object 'imps' not found #pool results using Raghunathan et al 2003 rules syntheticPool(fits) #> Error in eval(expr, envir, enclos): object 'fits' not found
